newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Sweden finmin - EMU decision must match public view.
newsitem.headline: Sweden finmin - EMU decision must match public view.

text.p: Sweden's Finance Minister Erik Asbrink said on Wednesday a decision regarding Swedish membership in Europe's economic and monetary union (EMU) could not run counter to public opinion.
He also said he had seen no change in Swedish public opinion about EMU in the past six months.
"The government can not have a view which runs counter to public opinion on the EMU issue," Asbrink told journalists after a parliamentary European Affairs committee meeting.
"Overall I have not seen any considerable changes in the opinion picture in the last half year," Asbrink said.
He added that there would be no decision on EMU for a few weeks.
"You can estimate a few more weeks from today. In good time I will announce when this will happen so everyone can take part," he said.
Asbrink said that he would announce the view both on the behalf of the government and party leaders.
"It will also be my personal view," he said.

Although opinion polls have showed Swedes turning slightly more in favour of EMU, a Tuesday survey by pollster Sifo indictated that merely 26 percent gave a 1999 membership a nod, while 24 percent wanted to join at a later stage and 35 percent dismissed a link. The rest were undecided.
